title: 111_hr4192
content: The "Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area Act of 2010" defines terms like "public lands" and "Outstanding Natural Area" and designates the Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area. The Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area Act of 2010 establishes the Stornetta Outstanding Natural Area in Mendocino County, California to protect and enhance its historical, natural, cultural, and recreational values. The area is depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Secretary manages the Outstanding Natural Area in California to protect resources and allow only uses that further its purposes. Federal lands within the area are withdrawn from various activities under public land laws and mineral leasing laws. SEC. 3. MANAGEMENT OF THE STORNETTA OUTSTANDING NATURAL AREA. The Secretary must manage the Outstanding Natural Area to conserve its unique values and only allow uses that further its purposes. A comprehensive management plan must be completed within 3 years to guide long-term management of the public lands within the area. The management plan for the Outstanding Natural Area must ensure protection of resources and values, propose minimal facilities, and include cultural resources management strategies. It should be developed in consultation with government agencies and with public participation. The management plan for the Outstanding Natural Area emphasizes resource preservation, education, and scientific uses, with a focus on enforcing relevant acts. Cooperative agreements may be entered into with various agencies to implement the plan effectively. The Secretary may authorize research activities within the Outstanding Natural Area to support the management plan. Lands adjacent to the area may be acquired through donation or exchange with willing parties. Any lands adjacent to the Outstanding Natural Area acquired by the United States after the enactment of this Act shall be added to and administered as part of the area. Overflights, including military and commercial flights, are not restricted within the area. The Act allows for flight training routes over the Outstanding Natural Area and modifications to low-level overflights above the Gulf of the Farallones National Marine Sanctuary. It also ensures that law enforcement activities and Native American access for cultural and religious purposes are not affected within the area. The Act allows for flight training routes over the Outstanding Natural Area and modifications to low-level overflights above the Gulf of the Farallones National Marine Sanctuary. It also ensures that law enforcement activities and Native American access for cultural and religious purposes are not affected within the area. The Secretary may temporarily close specific portions of the area to protect the privacy of traditional cultural and religious activities by federally recognized Indian tribes or communities, with access consistent with the American Indian Religious Freedom Act. The designation of the area does not create buffer zones. Activities outside the Outstanding Natural Area that are not consistent with the Act's purposes can be seen or heard within the area without precluding such activities up to the boundary of the area.
